simone

KJV Galatians 6: 6-9:
 
Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.
 
 For he that soweth to his flesh shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth to the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting.
 
 And let us not be weary in well doing: for in due season we shall reap, if we faint not.

 This is the Apostle Paul in a letter to the congregation in Galatia.
 
 Galatia was in what is present day Turkey:
 
Ancient Galatia was an area in the highlands of central Anatolia in modern Turkey. Galatia was named for the immigrant Gauls from Thrace, who settled here and became its ruling caste in the 3rd century BC, following the Gallic invasion of the Balkans in 279 BC. It has been called the "Gallia" of the East, Roman writers calling its inhabitants "Galli".

 Galatia - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

simone

From Paul's Second letter to the Thessalonians in which he admonishes that congregation that they should not tolerate freeloaders because of the importance of their mission:
 II Thessalonians 3:8-13:
 
Neither did we eat any man's bread for nought; but wrought with labour and travail night and day, that we might not be chargeable to any of you:
 
 Not because we have not power, but to make ourselves an example unto you to follow us.
 
 For even when we were with you, this we commanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat.
 
 For we hear that there are some which walk among you disorderly, working not at all, but are busybodies.
 
 Now them that are such we command and exhort by our Lord Jesus Christ, that with quietness they work, and eat their own bread.
 
 But ye, brethren, be not weary in well doing.

 Paul's words were directed to a specific people because of a specific problem, his words were not meant as a wholesale endorsement of capitalism.
Jo Bennett

Nor, even if they are taken as a general statement, do they endorse capitalism. Everyone with the ability to work should do suitable work if it is available. It just needs to be recognised that raising one's children is work like any other, and parents who want to raise their children well should be supported in doing so. Capitalism works on the basis that only work of value to someone with money counts as work, no matter what its ultimate value.
